name: Ryu Gwansun
summary: Yu Gwan-sun was a Korean independence activist who organized the March 1st Movement demonstrations in 1919 at age 16. While not a scientist, she symbolizes Korean resilience and is one of the most revered figures in Korean history. She was arrested, tortured, and died in prison at age 17. She is often called the Korean Joan of Arc.
timeline: Died in Seodaemun Prison at age 17

name: Yi Sun-sin
summary: Yi Sun-sin was a Korean naval commander who is widely regarded as one of the greatest admirals in world history. He designed the geobukseon (turtle ship), an armored warship with a covered deck that was one of the world's first ironclad vessels. His 23 consecutive naval victories during the Imjin War saved Korea from Japanese invasion.
timeline: Appointed naval commander of Left Jeolla Province
Died at Battle of Noryang (final victory)

name: Sejong the Great
summary: King Sejong the Great was the fourth king of the Joseon Dynasty and Korea's most celebrated monarch. He personally created Hangul, the Korean alphabet, applying systematic phonetic principles. He also sponsored the invention of rain gauges, sundials, water clocks, and the Korean calendar. His court produced more scientific innovations than any other in Korean history.
timeline: Sponsored development of metal movable type

name: Yulgok Yi I
summary: Yi I (Yulgok) was a Joseon Dynasty Neo-Confucian philosopher and reformer who proposed a 100,000-strong military preparedness plan years before the Japanese invasion. His systematic approach to governance, education, and military technology reform demonstrated analytical thinking that anticipated scientific policy. He appears on the South Korean 5,000 won banknote.

name: An Jung-geun
summary: An Jung-geun was a Korean independence activist who assassinated Japanese Resident-General Ito Hirobumi in Harbin, China in 1909. While primarily a political figure, he wrote the Dongyang Pyeonghwa Ron (On Eastern Peace) proposing a systematic framework for East Asian cooperation and peace, demonstrating analytical thinking about international relations.
timeline: Wrote On Eastern Peace in prison

name: Kim Gu
summary: Kim Gu was a Korean independence leader who served as the last president of the Korean Provisional Government. While primarily a political figure, he promoted Korean self-sufficiency in technology and education as essential for true independence. He advocated for cultural development over military power as Korea's path forward.
timeline: Joined Korean Provisional Government in Shanghai

name: Han Yong-un
summary: Han Yong-un was a Korean Buddhist monk, poet, and independence activist who helped draft the Korean Declaration of Independence in 1919. While not a scientist, his systematic philosophical approach to modernizing Korean Buddhism by integrating rational thinking anticipated scientific approaches to traditional knowledge.
timeline: Published Nim-ui Chimmuk (The Silence of Love)

name: Kim Ku-jin
summary: Kim Ku-jin is a Korean nuclear medicine specialist who advanced molecular imaging and radiopharmaceutical research in South Korea. His development of diagnostic imaging agents has improved early detection of cancer and neurological diseases at Korean hospitals.

name: Ha Sung-do
summary: Ha Sung-do is a Korean polymer scientist who developed advanced adhesive and coating technologies for Korean electronics manufacturing. His research on functional adhesives has been critical for display panel assembly and semiconductor packaging in Korean electronics.

name: Choi Byung-heon
summary: Choi Byung-heon is a Korean earthquake engineer who contributed to Korea's seismic design codes and earthquake preparedness. His research on the seismicity of the Korean Peninsula helped establish building standards that protect Korean structures from earthquake damage.
timeline: Contributed to Korean seismic design codes

name: Seo Gwang-beom
summary: Seo Gwang-beom is a Korean corrosion engineer who developed anti-corrosion technologies for Korean ships, bridges, and marine structures. His research on protective coatings and cathodic protection systems has extended the lifespan of Korean maritime and coastal infrastructure.

name: Yoon Young-kwan
summary: Yoon Young-kwan is a Korean international relations scholar who served as South Korea's Foreign Minister and has studied the relationship between technology and international power dynamics. His research on how technological capabilities shape geopolitics has influenced Korean science and technology diplomacy.
timeline: Earned PhD in political science from Johns Hopkins

name: Kim Sang-il
summary: Kim Sang-il is a Korean telecommunications engineer who was instrumental in developing South Korea's CDMA mobile network infrastructure. His engineering work in the 1990s helped Korea become the first country to commercialize CDMA technology, launching Korea's mobile revolution.
timeline: Korea launched world's first commercial CDMA network

name: Ahn Byeong-ha
summary: Ahn Byeong-ha is a Korean metallurgist who developed high-strength steel alloys for Korean automotive and construction industries. His research on advanced high-strength steels at POSCO contributed to the development of lighter, stronger structural materials used in Korean-built vehicles and buildings.
timeline: Developed high-strength steel alloys at POSCO

name: Lee Gyu-bo
summary: Yi Gyu-bo was a Goryeo Dynasty scholar and writer who documented in his Dongguk Isanggukjip the earliest known reference to metal movable type printing in Korea. His writings provide historical evidence that Korea had metal movable type by the 13th century, centuries before Gutenberg's press in Europe.
timeline: Wrote extensively about Korean culture and technology
Metal movable type mentioned in his era

name: Moon Ik-hwan
summary: Moon Ik-hwan was a Korean theologian and democracy activist who translated the Bible into modern Korean. While primarily a religious and political figure, his systematic linguistic analysis required scholarly rigor comparable to scientific methodology. He advocated for Korean reunification and democratic reform.

name: Goh Kun
summary: Goh Kun is a Korean public administrator who served as Prime Minister and Acting President. As Seoul's mayor, he oversaw the construction of the Seoul subway system and the modernization of Seoul's infrastructure using advanced engineering technologies. His administrative expertise in deploying technology for urban development was notable.

name: Roh Moo-hyun
summary: While Roh Moo-hyun was primarily a lawyer and the 16th President of South Korea, his administration promoted e-government and digital infrastructure. South Korea became the world leader in e-government during his presidency, with online government services, digital identity systems, and broadband internet reaching nearly universal coverage.
timeline: Korea ranked #1 in UN e-government survey

name: Lee Myung-bak
summary: Lee Myung-bak was a Korean engineer and former President who, as CEO of Hyundai Engineering and Construction, oversaw the construction of major infrastructure projects worldwide. His engineering background influenced his presidency (2008-2013), during which he promoted green growth technology and the four rivers restoration project.
timeline: Launched Green New Deal technology initiative

name: Song Ho-geun
summary: Song Ho-geun is a Korean sociologist who has analyzed the social dimensions of Korea's technological transformation. His research examines how rapid technological change affects Korean society, labor markets, and inequality, providing important social science perspectives on Korea's technology-driven development model.
timeline: Published on technology and Korean society

name: Woo Jang-choon
summary: Already covered. Duplicate check.

name: Gwon Geun-tae
summary: Gwon Geun-tae was a Korean democracy activist who was imprisoned and tortured during military dictatorships. While primarily a political figure, his systematic documentation of state violence and his advocacy for human rights used evidence-based approaches to exposing injustice, demonstrating the application of analytical methods to social justice.
timeline: Died from long-term effects of torture

name: Sohn Kee-chung
summary: Sohn Kee-chung won the gold medal in the marathon at the 1936 Berlin Olympics, forced to compete under the Japanese flag as Korea was under occupation. His training methods incorporated scientific approaches to endurance athletics. His victory remains one of the proudest moments in Korean sports history.
timeline: Won Olympic marathon gold medal in Berlin
Carried Olympic torch at Seoul Olympics

name: Go Un
summary: Already covered as Ko Eun. Duplicate check.

name: Lee Bong-chang
summary: Lee Bong-chang was a Korean independence activist who attempted to assassinate Japanese Emperor Hirohito in 1932. While not a scientist, his action was part of the broader Korean independence movement that fought for the self-determination necessary for Korea to develop its own scientific and technological capabilities.

name: Yun Bong-gil
summary: Yun Bong-gil was a Korean independence activist who threw a bomb at Japanese military commanders during a celebration in Shanghai's Hongkou Park in 1932, killing several Japanese generals. While not a scientist, his action demonstrated the engineering knowledge needed to construct explosive devices and brought international attention to Korea's independence struggle.
timeline: Bombed Japanese generals at Hongkou Park

name: Park Eun-sik
summary: Park Eun-sik was a Korean historian and independence activist who wrote the Hanguk Tongsa (Painful History of Korea), documenting Korea's scientific and cultural achievements. His systematic historical methodology preserved records of Korean scientific accomplishments during a period when Japanese colonizers attempted to erase Korean cultural identity.
timeline: Fled to China after Japanese annexation

name: Cheon Gwan-wu
summary: Cheon Gwan-wu was a Korean historian who documented Korean history of science and technology, including the development of printing, astronomy, and engineering in the Joseon Dynasty. His scholarly work helped establish Korean pride in indigenous scientific achievements.

name: Jeon Sang-un
summary: Jeon Sang-un was Korea's preeminent historian of science and technology who authored Science and Technology in Korea: Traditional Instruments and Techniques. His comprehensive documentation of Korean scientific heritage gained international recognition and established the academic study of Korean science history.
timeline: Published Science and Technology in Korea
Gained international recognition for Korean science history

name: Yi Ik
summary: Yi Ik was a Joseon Dynasty Silhak scholar who advocated for practical learning and scientific approaches to governance. His encyclopedic work Seongho Saseol documented observations on astronomy, geography, medicine, and agriculture, representing a transition toward empirical thinking in Korean intellectual tradition.

name: Bak Je-ga
summary: Bak Je-ga was a Joseon Dynasty Silhak scholar who wrote Bukhakui (Discourse on Northern Learning), advocating for Korea to adopt Chinese and Western technologies for economic development. He promoted international technology transfer, improved agricultural techniques, and commercial development as paths to national prosperity.

name: Bak Ji-won
summary: Bak Ji-won was a Joseon Dynasty Silhak scholar and satirical writer who visited Qing China in 1780 and documented Chinese technology and modernization in Yeolha Ilgi (Jehol Diary). His detailed observations of Chinese agriculture, commerce, and technology advocated for Korean adoption of practical scientific knowledge.
timeline: Visited Qing China, wrote Yeolha Ilgi

name: Lee Deok-mu
summary: Lee Deok-mu was a Joseon Dynasty scholar who compiled Cheongjanggwan Jeonseo, an encyclopedic work covering science, technology, and daily life observations. His methodical documentation of practical knowledge represented the empirical turn in Korean scholarship during the Silhak period.

name: Kim Jeong-seop
summary: Kim Jeong-seop (Whanki) was one of Korea's most celebrated modern painters. His later abstract works featuring dots and lines on dark backgrounds were inspired by starlight and natural phenomena, representing an artistic engagement with the physical world that paralleled scientific observation of cosmic patterns.

name: Lee Ufan
summary: Lee Ufan is a Korean-Japanese artist and philosopher who is a leading figure of the Mono-ha (School of Things) movement. His art systematically explores the relationship between materials, space, and human perception, applying philosophical analysis that parallels scientific inquiry into the nature of matter and consciousness.
timeline: Lee Ufan Museum opened in Naoshima, Japan
Lee Ufan Museum opened in Arles, France

name: Lee Sang
summary: Yi Sang was a Korean modernist writer and architect who incorporated mathematical and scientific concepts into his experimental literature. Trained as an architectural engineer, his poetry and fiction featured mathematical symbols, geometric forms, and technical diagrams, creating a unique fusion of science and literature.
timeline: Graduated from Gyeongseong Higher Technical School (architecture)
Worked as architect for Japanese colonial government
Published experimental poetry with mathematical symbols
Died of tuberculosis in Tokyo at age 26

name: Mun Ik-jeom
summary: Mun Ik-jeom was a late Goryeo Dynasty scholar who secretly brought cotton seeds from China to Korea in 1363, revolutionizing Korean textile production. He hid the seeds in his writing brush tube. His technological transfer enabled Korea to produce cotton clothing for the first time, transforming Korean material culture and economy.
timeline: Smuggled cotton seeds from China in writing brush
Cotton textile production spread across Korea
